text: I followed Alicia outside. The morning light was blinding, snowmelt dripping from the eaves as the street reflected a silvery glare.
She walked fast, but not in a hurry—more like someone executing a well-practiced routine. At every intersection, she didn’t look for signs, just turned.
"You know these streets a little too well."
"Mm."
"Don’t stop near the treeline. Something will crawl out of the ground."
She said it like she was warning me not to step in a puddle. I almost laughed on instinct—but couldn’t.
The town market was lively, as if nothing had happened at all. Shouts, hoofbeats, the smell of grease and bread blended together.
Alicia didn’t haggle. She named what she wanted outright. The vendor had just started to argue when one look from her made him immediately change his price.
"Three vials to stop bleeding. Two antidotes. Sealing charms—old paper only. Don’t give me fresh ink."
"…You even care how old the charm paper is?"
"Fresh ink attracts things that shouldn’t come."
She shoved everything into my arms at once. The weight made my shoulders go numb.
The stone road back to the inn ran alongside a pine forest. Wind made the treetops creak, the air sharp as a blade.
I was just about to quicken my pace when I heard a dull thud beneath my feet, like something turning over underground.
The soil split open. A beast with a stone-plated back clawed its way out, its green-lit eyes locked onto us.
"This is what you meant… right?"
"Don’t move."
She didn’t even draw her sword. She only pulled her glove up half an inch, like she was about to start an ordinary task.
"On the third step, it’ll pounce."
"How do you know—"
The beast growled. One step. Two. Three—and it lunged!
"Watch."
She finally drew her sword, the motion as fast as wind cutting across snow. A flash of silver—the beast’s forelimbs were severed cleanly.
The second strike was even cleaner, like cutting into wood whose grain she already knew. The stone shell shattered, the green light extinguished instantly.
The beast collapsed, its body dissolving into black smoke that sank back into the earth. All that remained was a scorched ring on the ground.
"You… made that look way too easy."
"That was a small one."
"Come on. Don’t stare."
